title.value: A hierarchical Bayesian brain parcellation framework for fusion of functional imaging datasets
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as given at the beginning of the provided text.
title.quote: A hierarchical Bayesian brain parcellation framework for fusion of functional imaging datasets

extractions.description: This paper proposes a hierarchical Bayesian framework for brain parcellation that integrates both task-based and resting-state fMRI datasets to create a probabilistic atlas. The proposed approach partitions the problem into a spatial arrangement model and a set of dataset-specific emission models, combining their strengths to generate improved group and individual brain parcellations.

type.justification: The paper focuses on proposing a new hierarchical Bayesian framework for brain parcellation and demonstrates its effectiveness through simulations and applications to various datasets rather than conducting empirical experiments.
type.quote: Here, we propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework that can learn a probabilistically defined brain parcellation across numerous task-based and resting-state datasets, exploiting their combined strengths.

name.justification: The paper focuses on developing models for brain parcellation using fMRI datasets, which is a core area within neuroimaging.
name.quote: Here, we propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework that can learn a probabilistically defined brain parcellation across numerous task-based and resting-state datasets, exploiting their combined strengths.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is to develop a framework for functional brain parcellation using Bayesian methods.
name.quote: Brain parcellations, which subdivide the brain into a discrete set of functionally distinct regions, are one important type of model with many practical applications.

name.justification: The paper discusses the integration of resting-state fMRI data into the proposed framework.
name.quote: Therefore, current atlases of functional brain organization are mainly based on single and homogeneous resting-state datasets.

name.justification: The paper also deals extensively with the integration and utilization of task-based fMRI data within their proposed framework.
name.quote: In recent years, an increasing number of high-quality task-based fMRI datasets that sample a broad range of tasks have become available.

name.justification: The paper proposes and uses a hierarchical Bayesian model for brain parcellation.
name.quote: Here, we propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework that can learn a probabilistically defined brain parcellation across numerous task-based and resting-state datasets, exploiting their combined strengths.

is_contributed.justification: This model is the primary contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: Here, we propose a hierarchical Bayesian framework that can learn a probabilistically defined brain parcellation across numerous task-based and resting-state datasets, exploiting their combined strengths.

is_executed.justification: The authors implement and test this model on various datasets as described in the paper.
is_executed.quote: We applied the new framework to a collection of seven task-based fMRI datasets (Table 1), with four of them containing a wide range of task conditions and three others related to specific functional domains, including executive function and motor movements.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared with other approaches and datasets within the paper.
is_compared.quote: We first confirmed that our probabilistic parcellation framework optimally learns group parcellation across sessions when comparing the performance to the parcellation learned from a single session.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This model is newly proposed in the current paper and there is no reference paper for it.

name.justification: The MDTB dataset is used in the framework to demonstrate its efficiency in brain parcellation.
name.quote: For this purpose, we first trained a group parcellation (17 parcels) on the first task set of the multi-domain task battery dataset (MDTB, (King et al., 2019)).

referenced_paper_title.value: Functional boundaries in the human cerebellum revealed by a multi-domain task battery
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper for the MDTB dataset used in the research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: multi-domain task battery dataset (MDTB, (King et al., 2019)).

name.justification: The high-resolution MDTB dataset is used within the proposed framework for validation and demonstration.
name.quote: We then attempted to validate the performance of the models on real imaging data. Here, we first used the IBC dataset. This dataset is ideal to test the integration of data from different sessions across the same participants, as it consists of 14 sessions some of which have similar tasks while others do not (Pinho et al., 2018, 2020).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the High-resolution MDTB dataset is not explicitly named in the text, but it is attributed to ongoing research by King et al. (2019).

name.justification: The dataset known as IBC is used for testing the proposed framework.
name.quote: We then attempted to validate the performance of the models on real imaging data. Here, we first used the IBC dataset

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the IBC dataset used in the research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Individual Brain Charting (IBC) dataset (Pinho et al., 2018, 2020).

name.justification: The dataset by Nakai & Nishimoto is used within the proposed framework for validation and demonstration.
name.quote: We then attempted to validate the performance of the models on real imaging data. Here, we first used the IBC dataset. This dataset is ideal to test the integration of data from different sessions across the same participants, as it consists of 14 sessions some of which have similar tasks while others do not (Pinho et al., 2018, 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: Quantitative models reveal the organization of diverse cognitive functions in the brain
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the Nakai & Nishimoto dataset used in the research.

name.justification: The dataset known as HCPUnrelated 100 is used for providing information on resting-state brain activity.
name.quote: To generate the resting-state functional connectivity (rs-FC) fingerprint of the cerebellar voxels from the HCP data set, a group Independent Component Analysis (ICA) was applied.

name.justification: SPM12 is used for pre-processing the fMRI datasets.
name.quote: The task-based datasets were pre-processed using either the SPM12 software package (Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, London, UK)

referenced_paper_title.justification: SPM12 is a well-known software package for neuroimaging data analysis, and no specific reference paper was necessary in the context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: SPM12 software package (Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, London, UK)

name.justification: The FSL library is also used for pre-processing the fMRI datasets.
name.quote: The task-based datasets were pre-processed using either the SPM12 software package (Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, London, UK) or the FSL library (Analysis Group, FMRIB, Oxford, UK).

referenced_paper_title.justification: FSL is a well-known software library for the analysis of fMRI data, and no specific reference paper was necessary in the context.
